div.head: Introduction
div.p: The research in high energy physics is predominantly based on the investigation of collisions between two particles at high energy. The collisions are studied through an analysis of the particles emerging from the interactioii. Along the trajectories ("tracks") of these particles, points ("hits") are recorded in subsequent layers af tracking detectors and calorimeters. The set of all recorded hits is called an "event". A typical event recorded in the ALEPH [l] detector at the LEP collider at CERN, Geneva, is shown as front and side view in figures la,h. In this detector of cylindrical shape, a hoinogeneous magnetic field parallel to the cylinder axis curves the tracks to helices.

For the checking of hard-and software and for presentation purposes, the visualizat,ion of single events is an efficient tool. However, coinplexity of events and detectors is iiicreasiiig continuously. As a consequence, pictures of detectors and events are getting more and more coinplicated and, in the extreme, may even get incoinprehensible. Therefore, new ways of displaying events are needed.

The techniques described below were developed for the ALEPH detector. Besides many engineers, techiiicians and software specialists, about 350 physicists scliaftlichen Forschung, Austria 'Supported by grant of Fonds zur Forderung der wissen-from all over the world took part in the coiistruct,ioii of the detector and are responsible for runiiiiig it, for providing the necessary software and for data evaluation.

div.head: The Three Dimensional V-Plot
div.p: Figures 5a,b shows TPC hits from two orthogonal [2, 51 sides in Y/X and p ' / Z . In the following we will try to visualize the full 3D coiiteiit of such hits in one 3D picture. The best known method of drawing a point in 3D is shown in figure 5c, where the 3D point is represented by two image points connected by a straight vertical line. Such pairs of points have three degrees of freedom. The two image points are gained through two linear projections overlaid upon the same image.

However, this method cannot be applied in the case of a large number of hits and does not allow compression. Therefore we will try to find two angular projections, which allow coinpression and, if overlaid, yield a picture, which is easy to understand. Figure 5d shows the same tracks as 5a,b in tlie conipressed angular projection p / R . The p/d projection yields a picture where tracks are already compressed and well separated (e). The angular projections p/R and cp/d describe best the interesting features of a track: p/R gives linear track images, where inoiiientuin and charge can be estimated from t,he gradient,, cp/d yields linear track images parallel to the p-axis, where track direct,ion, cp and il, can be est,iniated, hut not momentum and charge.

Figure 5f shows the overlay of cp/(d + k . D) and p/(d -.k . D). Normal, low curva-ture helices give images in the form of a "V", hence the name of the picture: "V-Plot" .

The V's are images, which are easy to recognize due to their siiiiple pattern and the high level of track compression. The position of the V gives the track direction ('p and d ) , the V-direction (i.e.upwards or downwards) gives the sign of the curvature (= charge of the particle), the angle between the V arms is a measure of tlie particle momentum. It is the aim of 3D tracking detectors to measure just these quantities, which can be easily estimated visually from the V-plot, without relying on pattern recognition programs. Due to the high track compression, deviations from exact helices are enlarged (see the kink of track 8 in figure 5). The measuring errors of the TPC get also visible, a necessary condition for thorough checking (see also discussion above).

Another aim of visual analysis is to recognize particle correlations. Tracks close to each other in space are close in the V-Plot. Tracks which cross in space are displayed as V's, where the two arms cross each other at the same value of 'p. From the V-plot in figure 5f one can deduce that there is no' pair of tracks crossing in space except for tracks 2 and 5, which have the starting point in common (i.e. one sees the decay of a neutral particle into a positive and a negative one). It was shown elsewhere [3, 4, 51, that the V-Plot technique C a l i be successfully applied for the visualization of data from other detector configurations, especially in the case of events with so many tracks, that other projections fail.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Tlie complexity of data from experiments in high energy physics limits the use of conventional 2D and 3D methods. When taking into account the predomiiiantly radial structure of the data, one is led to apply nonlinear transformations to generate good pictures. 3D data can be visualized by overlaying appropriate symmetric 2D projections, which leads to the V-Plot. However, tlie price to be paid is the use of more abstract representations. In short, the purpose of visual representations, namely to transfer data from the computer to the human brain, can still be accomplished.
